First off, let me say that Warren and his young son are a delight. Watching them interact was a great reminder that there is a lot of good left in this world and reason to be hopeful for the future.
When considering a stay at Warren's place, I would encourage you to think of it more along the lines of a close friend who invites you to stop off at his place on your way through town; instead of a traditional Bed and Breakfast setup where the host caters to your every need. Warren's a hard-working father who is extremely busy trying to keep food on the table and spend some quality time with his son. The guest wing of the house is very well-kept and prepared for your stay, but the living and kitchen areas you pass through on the way to the guest rooms are clearly the domain of Warren and his boy. Going in the front door, you're greeted by a collection of work clothes (big and small), a kitchen with well-used appliances and a multitude of toys scattered under the big-screen T.V. Warren invites you to make free use of the living and kitchen areas, but you need to understand this is his home, not a resort.
The guest wing is off the side of the living area and includes a full bath and two bedrooms with comfortable king-size beds. There's a sofa in one room and a glider in the other for additional sitting options. The bath includes plenty of clean towels and other necessities (just be patient while waiting for the hot water to arrive, it will get there). You can cook in the kitchen and watch T.V. in the living room. The T.V. has a good selection of streaming services (Netflicks, Prime, etc.). Warren and his son often move into the private wing of the house to allow guests time in the common areas. Overall, the house is comfortable and fully functional.
The location is about five miles west of Winnemucca just north of I-80. The house sits about 400 yards off the road and overlooks a high-desert valley to the north and imposing mountains in the distance. You have to weave your way through some equipment and machinery parts on your way to the house, and you'll likely be greeted by Warren working on a tractor or truck in front of the shop as you drive in. He just waves and tells you, "The house is open." In front of the house is more evidence that a young boy lives here and his father is too busy to worry about making the place look pretty. For that, you'll need to walk down the hill.
Just north of the house is a lane leading down the hill to a wonderful collection of old corrals, outbuildings and a grassy area set up for picnics and group events. The corrals house several long-horn cattle and off the side of the parking area is a great sand hill where the kids can play with trucks and other toys generously left by Warren's son. My dog loved stalking the pigeons perched around the corral, and the adjacent fields provide a perfect place for both dogs and people to stretch their legs. It's in this area that you get a true feel for the ranch.
For anyone looking for a place out of town and away from the casino/restaurant areas in Winnemucca, Warren's place is perfect. It's quiet and the views of the mountains and desert from the two guest rooms are spectacular. You just have to understand that this is his home and a working ranch. Also, Warren's old dog moves freely in and out of the house, so keep your dogs on a leash or they're likely to follow the ranch dog through the pet doors and take off to explore.
